title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary shall organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of veterans. Each network must implement national goals of the Department within their associated medical centers. The Secretary ensures each Veterans Integrated Service Network maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations, managing a regional budget aligned with Department guidelines, and using national metrics for system development. The Secretary ensures high quality healthcare delivery in the Veterans Integrated Service Networks by reducing duplicate functions and promoting collaboration and cooperation. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation within each Veteran Integrated Service Network to maximize patient care, safety, and research effectiveness. This includes assessing consolidation of functions with other networks, Veterans Benefits Administration, National Cemetery Administration, and Department of Defense offices and facilities. The Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies assisting veterans, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other Federal Government offices are included in the collaboration efforts overseen by the Secretary. The Secretary ensures that Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices. Each network has one headquarters co-located with a VA medical center, with a limited number of employees. The Secretary reports to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs annually. The Secretary must submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding employment at the headquarters of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including the number of employees, their titles, and positions within the network. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, including assessing employment impact on the Department's budget. The report is submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs every three years. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs with recommendations for improvement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single networks to streamline operations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single networks to streamline operations. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17 and 18, 19 and 20, and 21 and 22 will be combined into single networks. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single networks to streamline operations. Headquarters will be retained in the same location as before, and any additional headquarters will be eliminated to meet requirements. Reemployment assistance will be provided for individuals whose positions are eliminated to find new employment within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks to be co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers as required by the Act. A plan for implementation must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks to be co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. If a lease renewal or new lease is needed, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the reasons for such action. The report should include a list of medical centers with underutilized space. The report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs must include details on the network of headquarters with underutilized buildings at medical centers, the cost comparison between current and new leases, and the square footage to be leased. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will evaluate finance operations and compliance activities, reporting to the Under Secretary of Health. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks in outreach to veterans, programs for women veterans, homelessness programs, energy consumption, and other relevant operations. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors for regional support centers, which will be located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers unless approved by Congress. The Secretary must provide a report on the reasons for choosing a location for the regional support center that is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The report should include a list of underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, the cost of the lease if one is engaged, and the square footage to be leased. The Secretary must transfer employees from headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
